dictationText: 48-year-old female with chronic diarrhea for past 4 months, typically 4-5 loose stools daily. Reports upper right quadrant discomfort after meals. Patient has noted darkening of skin on knuckles and neck folds. Recent lab work shows mildly elevated ferritin and transaminases. Family history significant for father with cirrhosis of "unknown cause." Order abdominal ultrasound to evaluate for possible gallbladder disease.

diagnosisCodes.description: Nonspecific elevation of levels of transaminase

parsedResponse.feedback: Appropriate initial imaging for RUQ pain and abnormal LFTs. Consider adding hemochromatosis screening to workup given family history of cirrhosis, elevated ferritin, and skin changes suggestive of bronze diabetes.

diagnosisCodes.description: Other symptoms and signs involving eating and feeding habits

procedureCodes.description: Ultrasound, abdominal, real time with image documentation; limited (e.g., single organ, quadrant, follow-up)

suggestedICD10Codes.description: Nonspecific elevation of levels of transaminase and lactic acid dehydrogenase [LDH]

parsedResponse.feedback: Abdominal ultrasound is appropriate for evaluating potential gallbladder disease in a patient with RUQ pain and abnormal LFTs. Consider additional workup for hereditary hemochromatosis given skin changes, elevated ferritin, and family history of cirrhosis.

suggestedICD10Codes.description: Disorder of gallbladder in diseases classified elsewhere

suggestedCPTCodes.description: Ultrasound, abdominal, real time with image documentation; limited (eg, single organ, quadrant, follow-up)

parsedResponse.feedback: Abdominal ultrasound is appropriate for evaluating gallbladder pathology in a patient with chronic diarrhea and upper quadrant discomfort.
